info.name: SIEMENS_DIS_ALM_POLARION_OSLC
info.description:
Before using the collection, set the values for the variables:

 - **polarionHost**
 - **polarionPort**
 - **polarionApplicationName**
 - **oauthConsumerAppName_inp**
 - **oauthConsumerAppSecret_inp**

Then, run **1.Get_RootServices**  
Afterwards, go through OAuth 1.0 hell starting with **2.1.Get_Consumer_Key**  
Please note that steps **2.2.Approve_Consumer_Key** and **2.4.Authorize_Requested_Token** require user interaction, please refer to the Visualize tab for links to open them in the browser

After receiving the access token, go to step **3.1.Get_Servcie_Provider_Catalog** and then enjoy your journey through the Polarion OSLC resources

    <rdf:Description rdf:about="http://localhost/polarion/oslc/services/projects/library/workitems/WI-2">
        <dcterms:type>Requirement</dcterms:type>
        <dcterms:title>System Feature 1</dcterms:title>
        <dcterms:description><span class="Apple-style-span" style="font-style: italic;">Don’t really say “System Feature 1.” State the feature name in just a few words.<br/></span> <span class="Apple-style-span" style="font-weight: bold;"><span class="Apple-style-span" style="font-style: italic;"><br/>Description and Priority</span><span class="Apple-style-span" style="font-weight: normal;"><span class="Apple-style-span" style="font-style: italic;"><br/>Provide a short description of the feature and indicate whether it is of High, Medium, or Low priority. You could also include specific priority component ratings, such as benefit, penalty, cost, and risk (each rated on a relative scale from a low of 1 to a high of 9).</span></span></span><span class="Apple-style-span" style="font-style: italic;"><br/></span><span class="Apple-style-span" style="font-weight: bold;"><span class="Apple-style-span" style="font-style: italic;"><br/>Stimulus/Response Sequences<br/></span></span><span class="Apple-style-span" style="font-style: italic;">List the sequences of user actions and system responses that stimulate the behavior defined for this feature. These will correspond to the dialog elements associated with use cases.<br/></span><span class="Apple-style-span" style="font-weight: bold;"><span class="Apple-style-span" style="font-style: italic;"><br/>Functional Requirements</span></span><span class="Apple-style-span" style="font-style: italic;"><br/>Itemize the detailed functional requirements associated with this feature. These are the software capabilities that must be present in order for the user to carry out the services provided by the feature, or to execute the use case. Include how the product should respond to anticipated error conditions or invalid inputs. Requirements should be concise, complete, unambiguous, verifiable, and necessary. Use “TBD” as a placeholder to indicate when necessary information is not yet available</span>.</dcterms:description>

        <j.0:priority>Lowest</j.0:priority>
        <dcterms:title>Operating Environment</dcterms:title>
        <dcterms:identifier>WI-74</dcterms:identifier>
        <dcterms:type>Requirement</dcterms:type>
        <dcterms:description><em>Describe the environment in which the system will be used and define the major availability, reliability, performance, and integrity requirements. This information will significantly influence the definition of the system’s architecture. Consider questions such as:<br/></em> <ul><li><em>Are the users widely distributed geographically or located close to each other? How many time zones are they in?</em></li><li><em>When do the users in various locations need to access the system?</em></li><li><em>Where is the data generated and used? How far apart are these locations? Does the data from multiple locations need to be combined?</em></li><li><em>Are specific maximum response times known for accessing data that might be stored remotely?</em></li><li><em>Can the users tolerate service interruptions or is continuous access to the system critical for the operation of their business?</em></li><li><em>What access security controls and data protection requirements are needed?</em></li></ul></dcterms:description>
        <dcterms:modified rdf:datatype="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema#dateTime">2023-01-15T14:15:28.146Z</dcterms:modified>

    <rdf:Description rdf:about="http://localhost/polarion/oslc/services/projects/library/workitems/WI-68">
        <j.0:status>Draft</j.0:status>
        <j.0:type>Requirement</j.0:type>
        <dcterms:title>Scope of Initial Release</dcterms:title>
        <oslc:shortTitle>WI-68</oslc:shortTitle>
        <dcterms:description><span class="Apple-style-span" style="font-style: italic;">Describe the intended major features that will be included in the initial release of the product. Consider the benefits the product is intended to bring to the various customer communities, and generally describe the product features and quality characteristics that will enable it to provide those benefits. Avoid the temptation to include every possible feature that any potential customer category might conceivably want some day. Focus on those features and product characteristics that will provide the most value, at the most acceptable development cost, to the broadest community.</span></dcterms:description>

        <dcterms:title>Scope and Limitations</dcterms:title>
        <dcterms:modified rdf:datatype="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema#dateTime">2023-01-15T14:15:28.146Z</dcterms:modified>
        <rdf:type rdf:resource="http://open-services.net/ns/rm#Requirement"/>
        <j.0:priority>Lowest</j.0:priority>
        <dcterms:identifier>WI-67</dcterms:identifier>
        <dcterms:type>Requirement</dcterms:type>
        <dcterms:description><span style="font-style: italic;" class="Apple-style-span">The project scope defines the concept and range of the proposed solution. It’s also important to define what will not be included in the product. Clarifying the scope and limitations helps to establish realistic expectations of the many stakeholders. It also provides a reference frame against which proposed features and requirements changes can be evaluated. Proposed requirements that are out of scope for the envisioned product must be rejected, unless they are so beneficial that the scope should be enlarged to accommodate them (with accompanying changes in budget, schedule, and/or resources).</span></dcterms:description>
        <dcterms:created rdf:datatype="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema#dateTime">2008-10-02T19:26:46.051Z</dcterms:created>
    </rdf:Description>

    <rdf:Description rdf:about="http://localhost/polarion/oslc/services/projects/library/workitems/WI-72">
        <dcterms:title>Stakeholder Profiles</dcterms:title>
        <dcterms:created rdf:datatype="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema#dateTime">2008-10-02T19:29:37.27Z</dcterms:created>
        <j.0:type>Requirement</j.0:type>
        <j.0:previousStatus>open</j.0:previousStatus>
        <dcterms:description><span style="font-style: italic;" class="Apple-style-span">Stakeholders are individuals, groups, or organizations that are actively involved in a project, are affected by its outcome, or can influence its outcome. The stakeholder profiles identify the customers for this product and other stakeholders, and states their major interests in the product. Characterize business-level customers, target market segments, and different user classes, to reduce the likelihood of unexpected requirements surfacing later that cannot be accommodated because of schedule or scope constraints. For each stakeholder category, the profile includes the major value or benefits they will receive from the product, their likely attitudes toward the product, major features and characteristics of interest, and any known constraints that must be accommodated.<br/>Examples of stakeholder value include:<br/></span><ul><li><span style="font-style: italic;" class="Apple-style-span">improved productivity</span></li><li><span style="font-style: italic;" class="Apple-style-span">reduced rework</span></li><li><span style="font-style: italic;" class="Apple-style-span">cost savings</span></li><li><span style="font-style: italic;" class="Apple-style-span">streamlined business processes</span></li><li><span style="font-style: italic;" class="Apple-style-span">automation of previously manual tasks</span></li><li><span style="font-style: italic;" class="Apple-style-span">ability to perform entirely new tasks or functions</span></li><li><span style="font-style: italic;" class="Apple-style-span">conformance to current standards or regulations</span></li><li><span style="font-style: italic;" class="Apple-style-span">improved usability or reduced frustration level compared to current applications</span></li></ul></dcterms:description>
        <dcterms:relation rdf:datatype="java:org.eclipse.lyo.oslc4j.core.model.Link">Link{to='http://localhost/polarion/oslc/services/projects/library/workitems/WI-99'; label='WI-99'}</dcterms:relation>
        <dcterms:modified rdf:datatype="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema#dateTime">2023-01-15T14:15:28.146Z</dcterms:modified>
        <j.0:priority>Lowest</j.0:priority>
        <j.0:status>Draft</j.0:status>
        <j.0:severity>Nice to Have</j.0:severity>
        <dcterms:type>Requirement</dcterms:type>
        <ldf:status>Draft</ldf:status>
        <oslc:serviceProvider rdf:resource="http://localhost/polarion/oslc/services/projects/library"/>

        <j.0:status>Draft</j.0:status>

        <rdf:type rdf:resource="http://open-services.net/ns/rm#Requirement"/>
        <oslc:serviceProvider rdf:resource="http://localhost/polarion/oslc/services/projects/library"/>
        <dcterms:description><span style="font-style: italic;" class="Apple-style-span">Describe the important business objectives of the product in a way that is quantitative and measurable. The value provided to customers is described in section 1.4, so this section should focus on the value provided to the business. This could include estimates of revenue or cost savings, return on investment analysis, or target release dates. Determine how success will be defined and measured on this project, and describe the factors that are likely to have the greatest impact on achieving that success. Include things within the direct control of the organization, as well as external factors. Establish measurable criteria to assess whether the business objectives have been met.</span></dcterms:description>
        <dcterms:relation rdf:datatype="java:org.eclipse.lyo.oslc4j.core.model.Link">Link{to='http://localhost/polarion/oslc/services/projects/library/workitems/WI-97'; label='WI-97'}</dcterms:relation>

        <dcterms:type>Requirement</dcterms:type>
        <dcterms:description><span style="font-style: italic;" class="Apple-style-span">Describe the needs of typical customers or market segments, including needs that are not yet met by the marketplace or by existing systems. You may wish to describe problems customers currently encounter that the new product will (or will not) address and how the product would be used by customers. Identify the customer hardware and software environment in which the product must operate. Define at a high level any known critical interface or performance requirements. Avoid including any design or implementation details. Present the requirements in a numbered list so that more detailed user or functional requirements can be traced to them.</span></dcterms:description>
        <dcterms:title>Customer or Market Needs</dcterms:title>

    <rdf:Description rdf:about="http://localhost/polarion/oslc/services/projects/library/workitems/WI-81">
        <dcterms:description>A test case specification shall aim to evaluate the operation of a key element or function of the<br/>system. For each test case, identify or specify<br/><br/> <span style="font-weight: bold;">Test items</span><br/>Identify and briefly describe the items and features to be exercised by this test case.<br/><br/> <span style="font-weight: bold;">Input specifications</span><br/>Specify inputs required to execute the test case. The inputs might be specified by value (with tolerances where appropriate),<br/>or by name. Specify also all required relationships between inputs (e.g., timing).<br/><br/> <span style="font-weight: bold;">Output specifications</span><br/>Specify outputs expected from executing the test case relevant to pass or fail criteria. (e.g., response time).<br/><br/> <span style="font-weight: bold;">Environmental needs</span><br/><ul><li>characteristics and configurations of required hardware</li><li>required system and application software</li><li>other special equipment or specially-trained personnel<br/></li></ul><span style="font-weight: bold;">Special procedural requirements</span><br/>Special constraints on test procedures that execute this test case<br/><br/> <span style="font-weight: bold;">Inter-case dependencies</span><br/>Test cases that must be executed before this test case should be linked using the "depends_on" link role.</dcterms:description>
        <j.0:type>Test Case</j.0:type>
        <dcterms:modified rdf:datatype="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema#dateTime">2023-01-15T14:15:28.146Z</dcterms:modified>

        <rdf:type rdf:resource="http://www.plm.automation.siemens.com/ldf#CoreBO"/>
